p-curvature and the Tate-valued Frobenius

Aug 21, 2020

In this post, I’d like to continue this series, and apologize for the delay. Some of what I will talk about in this post will appear in joint with Ben Antieau, but, as usual, this post will only cover my understanding of how the story should go. This means in particular that all mistakes and misunderstandings are mine, and that some statements are just philosophical musings that are only mine. This post will discuss broader implications than the current scope of my project with Ben, so that warning/disclaimer is even more applicable.

I would like to talk about -curvature in this post. Let me first give a classical recollection of -curvature, complain about it a bit, and then dualize to stop complaining.

The -curvature of a module with flat connection over a scheme (where is of characteristic ) is the failure of the map to commute with taking th powers. We discussed this a bit in the beginning of this post, so I’ll refer the reader there. The main thing to recall is that if is regarded as a D-module, then the -curvature is the morphism , where the first morphism sends to . The particular aspect of -curvature that I’d like to focus on is nilpotency. Namely, a connection on is said to have nilpotent -curvature if satisfies for some for all . Katz showed that if is a smooth projective morphism of smooth varieties, then the Gauss-Manin connection on has nilpotent -curvature; in particular, nilpotency is an obstruction to describing when a connection comes as a subquotient of a Gauss-Manin connection.

Now, I’m not too happy with this map sending to , because the sheaf of differential operators isn’t commutative, and that makes things more complicated. We will instead Koszul dualize, and understand nilpotency of the -curvature in terms of the de Rham complex of . To do so, we need to recall that a module with flat connection has zero -curvature if and only if it is the pullback of a quasicoherent -module along the relative Frobenius , equipped with the canonical connection. A module with flat connection has nilpotent -curvature if and only if it is in the thick subcategory of modules with flat connection generated by those ones with zero -curvature (and the length of the resolution by modules with zero -curvature is the nilpotence exponent of the -curvature).

Therefore, we would be done if we could characterize modules with zero -curvature in terms of the de Rham complex.
